Description: Terracotta theatre mask of a character from the New Comedy. Brow deeply furrowed above raised right eyebrow, nose small and snub, wide mouth gaping open. Eyes bulging. White coating with traces of red paint. Bottom half missing. Soft, fine orange fabric with a soapy texture.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Mask of the New Comedy, probably from the late 3rd or 2nd centuries BC (Burn and Higgins 2001, 2267, GR 1842,0728.750 from Melos dated 2nd to 1st century BC; GR 1856,1226.332 from Nola, Italy, dated 3rd to 2nd century BC). Fabric not Egyptian, probably East Greek or Greek.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DB.403) (Phase 3)
